comments.commentBody:
I am a physician who travels all over the country as a locum tenens doctor. I see 10 to 15 patients per day in the office and in the hospital. Most of these patients have serious illness. In the last seven years, I've practiced medicine from New York to Wyoming, from North Dakota to Virginia,

In every locality paints all have the same complaints about healthcare. Premiums are too expensive and deductibles are too high.

Lowering the cost of premiums and lowering deductibles while providing universal coverage and universal insurability to include even preexisting conditions is the mission. This can be accomplished with political will, flexibility and work.
The Republicans do a pretty good job of making life miserable also, unless you are rich.

Trump said the whole time that he was going to repeal Obamacare. He does not have detailed well thought out plan for any thing he promised. Answer to how was never provided except all solutions are going to be best and greatest. Still some people in Ohio, Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania put him over the top. Well elections have consequences - now things will go back to the way the were before Obamacare..
And you have a point as it pertains to this article?
LOL.  There is NO substance.  There is no politically correct solution for the Republicans.  They are in a trap of their own making.
Step one - remove for-profit insurance corporations.  Profit simply does not belong in healthcare--it then becomes healthcare prevention rather than healthcare delivery.
So Hillary has no coverage?

In fact, insurance companies have an incentive to keep prices high. They operate on a margin of the total healthcare spend: almost like real estate agents. Why get a cut of a 100,000 house when you can get a cut of a million dollar house instead!

The non-Medicade portion of the ACA is in free fall in many states. In CT it is an unmitigated disaster. Go to accesshealthct.com, type in your particulars and see for yourself. The insurance companies were given whatever increases they wanted this year, as they threatened to drop out all together.
The system is a deeply flawed, but Democratic politicians were/are too partisan to recognize it. In 2014, they sleezily didn't announce premium increases until after the elections. This time 'round someone must have been asleep at the switch, and the increases came out before the big vote. Can't help but think it gave a yoouge boost to The Donald.
Single payer healthcare insurance is not rocket science and is what we need (virtually ever other sophisticated economy has it), unless one is being bribed by the insurance lobby, which, sadly, is the only explanation for the system as we have it.
And you seriously think the Republicans are going to vote for single payer. Which by the way was what the DEMOCRATS wanted all along.
So since it is, as you claim, the republican plan - why are you so worried?

It's more like Medicaid for all sweetheart.

That's the problem. People from the upper west side don't want to sit in waiting rooms with poor people.
The word "no" does wonders.

and the dems plan is if you make less than 25k it is free, and if you make more, it cost you 20k for a family of four. That is what is called paycheck to paycheck.
The system is broke, has been broke for 20 years.

Step #1. There should be a National Lcensing System for healthcare providers.
State medical boards can still control state licensing but providers have to be licensed in the National System to treat patients with medicare and medicaid insurance.

Except that healthcare is a "pay or die" marketplace. It can never be a true free market. The "blackmail" aspect, or your-money-or-your-life effect, will always cause prices to be much higher than they should be. How do you solve that?
There are thousands of health insurers, not just three.
I have it on reliable word that the Republicans will replace Obamacare with their new plan:  "walk it off."

That's me since Obama care.  I go from zero out of pocket, to 600 per month since that so called affordable Healthcare act. And if I don't buy that affordable half oz of gold per month, the irs steels it.
and that's when you're young and in good heath. How much will it be when you're elderly and infirm?

It boggles my mind that people can even toy with the IDEA of throwing millions of Americans under the bus. You want to make America great again, but you want everyone to pull themselves up by their bootstraps while simultaneously clipping those bootstraps. Unbelievable.

Richard, you misrepresent what Clinton actually said, and what I said.
I didn't say money rules -- you did. I said the opposite -- that our motives are complicated, we are filled with cognitive biases, and economics are often secondary to less rational social behaviors.

That's not evil; just human. Since the beginning of recorded history, we know people have been prone to stupid, destructive behavior. Any review of history will show you that self-government is an outlier, and that a collapse under Trump is more likely to be a catalyst for fascism than for social democracy.

Our nation was designed on this sort of skepticism -- the fragmenting of power, the impossibility of big, rapid changes. Sometimes progress requires movement sideways, rather than directly forward, like a switchback trail up a steep cliff.

Sanders is a candidate, not a unique physical incarnation of social democracy or policy. Clinton included his ideas in the Dem platform. The tribalism of progressives deserting in anger, abandoning the power of their unity with Democrats, and ceding the field to proto-fascist Republicans is an example of the non-rational nature of political decisions. Purist progressives chose to charge straight up a sheer cliff instead of taking the Clinton switchback, and now we lie broken at the bottom of the cliff.

That is what I mean. Love and admiration and hurt led you to abandon a productive route, and find disaster. There's no phoenix here, just ashes.

Indeed. Old Doc. My husband retired as a primary care doc a few years ago. He made less per year than our daughter who's a teacher! That's the lot of primary-care doctors. He was a board-certified family practitioner. Everyone assumers physicians are paid gobs and wads of money. He worked 80-90 hours per week. I often figured that if you divided out hours by the money he made, he'd probably make about what people who who manage retail stores do on an hourly basis. All that with 12 years of school, four years of college, four years of medical school, and three years of residency. He missed just about every event in our children's lives when they were growing up. I bet the CEOs of United Healthcare, Aetna, Humana, etc., and their multi-million-dollar annual salaries, whose policies dictate what physicians can and cannot prescribe and what they get reimbursed, don't have to worry about missing events and holidays. Or that the phone will ring in the middle of the night because a patient is seriously ill or threatening suicide.

Concerned Citizen, what on earth does the supposed all whiteness of Europe have to do with OUR lack of affordable, universally accessible health care?

Here's one fact: the state of Texas recently cut off funding for women's health care, primarily for ideological reasons. Maternal mortality has soared.

This isn't the fault of the women, it's the fault of the politicians who are intent on victimizing them.

And nice job blaming the victims by the way. I salute you.

Step #3. There needs to be a donut hole in the individual cap for social security taxation system.
The first $125,000 annual income is subject to social security taxes. The next $175,000 is not subject to social security taxation. Starting at $401,000 social security taxes are again collected at 50% of the regular rate until $600,000 annual income, Starting at $601,000 regular social security taxes are again collected. The extra revenue should be diverted in the extra expenses for the healthcare insurance system.

ObamaCare big success is the take-all-comers, and Kids to 26 clauses.  But that could have been done stand-alone.  The biggest failure, is what always fails Dems policies.  Regulations up the nose, and no realistic plan on how to pay for it.  The GOP, are equally blind by thinking that america is still in the 50s. where the majority of the people were independent.  That ship has passed.  The issue today is the high cost. This will continue to vex both parties FOREVER, unless they work TOGETHER.

However, Kaiser has had disputes with its employee's unions, faced civil and criminal charges for patient dumping, faced action by regulators over the quality of care it provided, especially to patients with mental health issues, and has faced criticism from activists and action from regulators over the size of its cash reserves.  As of Dec. 31, 2015, the non-profit Kaiser Foundation Health Plan and Kaiser Foundation Hospitals entities reported a combined $1.9 billion in net income on $60.7 billion in operating revenues.

@Jerome. OK sir. Let me join the others in pointing out to you that people who use Obamacare DO WORK. Many are independent contractors or have their own small businesses and employ other people.

Obamacare saves lives. Repeat after me: Obamacare saves lives. It saves lives.

OK. Wanna rethink your comment now?
